item.title: The Secret History of SEAL Team 6
item.description: The unit best known for killing Osama bin Laden has been converted into a global manhunting machine with limited outside oversight.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI, NICHOLAS KULISH, CHRISTOPHER DREW, SERGE F. KOVALESKI, SEAN D. NAYLOR and JOHN ISMAY
item.media:description: Navy SEAL operators awaited a night mission to capture insurgent leaders near Falluja, Iraq, in July 2007.

item.title: Taliban Overrun Remote District in Northeastern Afghanistan
item.description: Taliban fighters overwhelmed security forces in the Yamgan district of Badakhshan Province, where the government’s influence has waned considerably over the past two years.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: South Korea Reports Nine New Cases in MERS Virus Outbreak
item.description: Five of the new cases announced Saturday stemmed from transmissions at Samsung Medical Center in Seoul, one of the country’s best hospitals.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Train passengers wore protective masks in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday. The outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome was traced to Pyeongtaek, about 35 miles south of the capital.

item.title: Leonid Plyushch, Ukrainian Mathematician and Soviet Dissident, Dies
item.description: Mr. Plyushch, a Ukrainian mathematician, became a leading political dissident, prompting the Kremlin to commit him to a mental asylum for a nightmarish three years of drugs and deprivation.
item.dc:creator: DAVID STOUT

item.title: Israel’s Allies in U.S. Challenge Boycott
item.description: Israel’s advocates in the United States, mirroring the reaction among many in Israel, are scrambling to respond to the pro-Palestinian economic and disinvestment campaign.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A sign in Bethlehem, in the West Bank, calls for a boycott of products from Israeli settlements in the occupied territories.

item.title: U.S. Was Warned of System Open to Cyberattacks
item.description: The same attackers who breached the records of millions of government workers appear to be behind similar thefts at Anthem and Premera Blue Cross, cybersecurity experts say.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: Millions of records for American workers were stolen from the Office of Personnel Management in Washington by hackers.

item.title: Days Before Election in Turkey, Blasts at Rally Kill 2
item.description: The explosions, which wounded more than 100, took place at a huge opposition political rally in a predominantly Kurdish city.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A protest on Friday after two explosions at a campaign rally for the opposition People’s Democratic Party in Diyarbakir. More than 100 were wounded; the cause has not been determined.

item.title: More Bodies Are Found as Yangtze Ship Is Lifted
item.description: With no hope of finding survivors in the submerged hull of a cruise ship that capsized this week with 456 people aboard, officials turned their attention on Friday to recovering the dead.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: The Oriental Star was lifted on Friday from the Yangtze River in China, four days after it capsized during a heavy storm.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Failed to Correct Violation of Landmark 1987 Arms Control Deal
item.description: At issue is the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, known as the I.N.F. Treaty, which the Obama administration says the Russians breached by testing a cruise missile.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Ukraine Repels Separatists in Fierce Fighting, Poroshenko Says
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko, speaking at a news conference in the capital, described the battle as a show of strength and resolve by his country’s military.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A Ukrainian convoy near Maryinka, west of Donetsk, on Thursday. Fighting there is some of the fiercest since I cease-fire was signed in February.

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: More Victims Reported in Helicopter Crash
item.description: An American military helicopter that crashed last month in the mountains east of Kathmandu was carrying five more passengers than had previously been reported.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: World Briefing: Republic of Congo: High School Students Protest After Exams Are Canceled Over Leak of Questions
item.description: Thousands of high school students pelted the police with stones and damaged property in violent protests Friday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Tariq Aziz, Top Aide and Fervent Ally of Saddam Hussein, Dies at 79
item.description: Mr. Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister and deputy prime minister, was for decades the most public face of Mr. Hussein’s government.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tariq Aziz, left, in 1992 at the United Nations as deputy prime minister of Iraq, talking with Chinmaya Rajaninath Gharekhan, the Indian delegate, at a meeting of the Security Council.

item.title: Czech Reality TV Show Makes a Game of Life Under Nazi Rule
item.description: A Czech series has, not surprisingly, stirred intense reactions about mixing such a dark period in history into an entertainment format more often associated with the Kardashians.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petr Klimes, right, a Czech stage and television actor, plays a Gestapo officer in "Holiday in the Protectorate."

item.title: Tsipras Declares Creditors’ Debt Proposal for Greece ‘Absurd’
item.description: The prime minister, in a speech to rally his party’s dissenters, took a defiant stand but said Athens’s negotiating strategy would “soon bear fruit.”
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A liquor store in Thessaloniki, Greece. The economy has shrunk after five years of austerity measures, and unemployment is high.

item.title: Some Germanwings Victims’ Remains to Be Returned on Schedule
item.description: The announcement by the airline’s parent company ended uncertainty for the families after the transfer was suspended because of a bureaucratic error.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Romanian President Calls for Premier to Resign Amid Graft Inquiry
item.description: Prime Minister Victor Ponta, who has been named as a suspect in 17 counts of forgery and other charges, said on Facebook that he would not step down.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Pakistan Says Court Has Freed 8 of 10 Accused in Attack on Malala Yousafzai
item.description: The men were tried by a secretive court, and a report released Friday contradicted the police, who said in April that all 10 had been sentenced to 25 years.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Malala Yousafzai after a news conference in Birmingham, England, last fall, when it was announced that she would receive the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: World Briefing: Frenchman in Vegetative State Can Be Taken Off Life Support, Court Rules
item.description: The case of Vincent Lambert, who was paralyzed in a car accident seven years ago, has been at the center of debates on end-of-life decisions in France.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: France Says It Opposes Boycotting Israel
item.description: The French foreign minister responded after a partly state-owned telecommunications company said it would seek to withdraw from the Israeli market.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
